metadata.title: Synthesis and characterization of silver nanoparticles supported on surface-modified poly(<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-vinylimidazale) as catalysts for the reduction of 4-nitrophenol
metadata.journal: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical

of AgNPs onto the PS-PVIm matrices (PS-PVIm-AgNPs) 2.5 Comparative catalytic activity of Type-I and Type-II PS-PVIm-AgNPs catalysts for the reduction of 4-nitrophenol 3 Results and discussions 3.1 IMAGE-HIGH-RES MOLCAA 8515 S1381-1169(12)00282-8 10.1016/j.molcata.2012.08.021 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 FT-IR spectrum of (a) and (b) Type-I PS-PVIm and Type-I PS-PVIm-AgNPs, (c) and (d) Type-II PS-PVIm and Type-II PS-PVIm-AgNPs. Fig. 2 (a) and (b) UV–vis spectrum of Type-I and Type-II PS-PVIm-AgNPs. Fig. 3 SEM image of (a) and (b) Type-I and Type-II PS-PVIm, (c) and (d) Type-I and Type-II PS-PVIm-AgNPs. Fig. 4 UV–vis spectrum of reduction of 4-NP using Type-I PS-PVIm-AgNPs. Fig. 5 Recycle efficiency of Type-I PS-PVIm-AgNPs for 4-NP reduction. Fig. 6 Effect of (a) [catalyst], (b) [NaBH4] and (c) [substrate] for reduction of 4-NP. Scheme 1 Preparation of PS-PVIm-AgNPs. Scheme 2 Reduction of 4-nitrophenol. Table 1 Comparative study for the reduction of 4-nitrophenol. Name of the catalyst Reduction of 4-NP k obs ×10−4 s−1 Type-I PS-VIm-AgNPs 5.12 Type-II PS-VIm-AgNPs 1.20 Synthesis and characterization of silver nanoparticles supported on surface-modified poly(N-vinylimidazale) as catalysts for the reduction of 4-nitrophenol Eagambaram Murugan ⁎ J. Nimita Jebaranjitham Department of Physical Chemistry, School of Chemical Sciences, University of Madras, Maraimalai Campus, Chennai 600025, Tamil Nadu, India ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +91 44 22202818/22202819; fax: +91 44 22352494. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Preparation of two types of polymer-immobilized silver nanoparticles catalysts. ► The activity of the catalysts was assessed based on reduction of 4-nitrophenol. ► The 6 fold enhancement of k obs noticed in Type-I catalyst than Type-II catalyst. ► Stable, efficient, eco-friendly, easy to prepare and easily recyclable many times. ► Heterogeneous nanocatalysts can be conveniently packed into column/flow reactors. Two types of bead-shaped stable heterogeneous nanoparticle catalysts, viz. polymer-supported poly(styrene) functionalized with poly(vinylimidazole) immobilized silver nanoparticles (PS-PVIm-AgNPs) were prepared from poly(styrene)-co-poly(N-vinylimidazole) polymer matrices derived from 2% (Type-I) and 10% (Type-II) cross-linking monomer divinylbenzene and AgNO3 as a metal precursor. The appearance of surface plasmon resonance peak at 422nm in UV and AgN(str,ring) peaks noticed at 1664cm−1 for Type-I and 1668cm−1 for Type-II catalysts in FT-IR confirms the immobilization of AgNPs onto PS-PVIm. The SEM and EDAX results prove that the Type-I catalyst has heterogeneous morphology with more white patches and enhanced amount of surface nitrogen and AgNPs than Type-II. The size of the AgNPs on Type-I and Type-II catalysts was measured as 10nm and 14.6nm from XRD, respectively. The comparative catalytic study for the reduction of 4-nitrophenol reveals that the pseudo-first order rate constant (k obs) for Type-I catalyst was relatively superior (k obs =5.12×10−4) than Type-II (k obs =1.20×10−4) due to the addition of high cross-linking load in Type-II. For the same reaction with Type-I catalyst, the variation of [substrate], [catalyst] and [NaBH4] was directly proportional to k obs. The stability and reusability of the catalyst were observed good and sustained even at six cycles. Keywords Poly(styrene) poly(N-vinylimidazole) Silver nanoparticles Heterogeneous nanoparticle catalyst Immobilization 4-Nitrophenol reduction 1 Introduction In the recent years, synthesis of metal nanoparticles (MNPs) has fascinated the scientists, because of their important applications in nanotechnology. Especially, the transition metal nanoparticles are prepared and used extensively since they exhibit unique physicochemical properties due to their size-induced quantum effects (large surface to volume ratio) and thus differ significantly from macroscopic metals. More particularly, NPs have potential applications especially in fabrication of electronic devices, ultrafast data communication, optical data storage, photochemical catalysts [1], sensors [2] and nonlinear optical materials [3]. Similarly, inorganic–polymer hybrid nanocomposite materials are used to exhibit excellent properties and have promising diverse applications in drug delivery systems, biological diagnostics and catalysis [4,5]. In general, physical methods like sonochemical reduction, photolytic reduction, radiolytic reduction, laser ablation, microwave, ultra sound metal evaporation–condensation [6–9] and chemical methods inclusive of reducing the metal ion precursors with reducing agents like alcohol, citrate, polyol, N2H4, Na3(C6H5O7)5 and borohydride [10–13] have been widely used for the preparation of metal nanoparticles. The encapsulation/stabilization of MNPs has usually been performed with variety of stabilizers like micelles [14], microgels [15], brushes [16], hollow capsules [17], macroporous resins [18], spheres [19], surfactant [20] and dendrimers [21]. These stabilizers in turn control the size of the MNPs and also prevent the aggregation. Normally, in the preparation of heterogeneous nanoparticle catalysts, apart from catalytic moiety/nanoparticles, the selection of catalyst support/matrices has also been paid greater attention to improve the performance of the catalyst. It is also obvious that, the inorganic supports/matrices have led to lower the catalytic performance because of their rigidity and also the distance between the surface and functional group is more. In contrast, organic matrixes (or) templates derived from polymers have always gained significant attention as they are inert, non-toxic, non-volatile, stable, flexible and reusable. Functional polymers like anionic (e.g. SO3H, COOH), cationic (e.g. N(R)+) or resins with organic groups containing carbonyl, hydroxyl, amino, amido, ester, nitrile, epoxy etc. [22,23] have been exploited extensively as efficient supports since they provide effective stabilizing framework and several binding sites for simultaneous interaction with the particle surface through their hetero atom that in turn act as ligands and the substrate thereby swelling in suitable liquid media. Thus, a polymeric support/templates always offer a good and higher specific supporting capacity. For example, imidazole containing macromolecules and its derivatives are of great interest due to the possibilities for the preparation of new support materials to exhibit ion exchange properties via complex formation with various metals [24] like Hg2+, Cu2+, Ni2+, Co2+, V3+ and Fe3+. The binding properties of N-vinyl imidazole are due to prevailing of electron donor nitrogen atom at position 3 of the imidazole ring [25]. Several studies on biocompatibility and protein enzyme separation have been carried out using the property of imidazole as a carrier agent for protein separation [26]. Silver NPs (AgNPs) have shown good antimicrobial properties and also they have drawn considerable interest because of their potential applications in the field of catalysis [27], surface enhanced Raman scattering studies [28], photographic processes [29] and biosensors [30]. In the earlier days, several routes have been developed to synthesize the AgNPs including in situ-chemical reduction [31], lithography [32], photolithography [33], and self assembly [34]. However, AgNPs undergo facile oxidation and aggregation and thus limits their further applications in many fields. The reduction of micro size silver into nanosize particles has helped to make the element highly effective and thus received a demand for several applications in the industry, medicine and technology. It can also be used as an ingredient for electro conduit, slurry, air/water purifiers, ingredient for inks used in inkjets and used as a nanoparticle catalyst for various homogeneous and heterogeneous reactions. p-Nitrophenol is one of the most important refractory pollutants that can occur in industrial and agricultural wastewater. In order to avoid this pollution, the concerned wastewater has been treated with different catalysts and that in turn converted the 4-nitrophenol into 4-aminophenol. This chemical normally been used as a precursor in the manufacture of many analgesic and antipyretic drugs such as paracetamol, phenacetin and acetanilide. It is also used as a potential intermediate in pharma industry and finds applications in photographic developer, anti-corrosion lubricant inhibitor, corrosion inhibitor and hair-dyeing agent [35]. Therefore, in view of the significance of 4-aminophenol, there is always a greater demand for the direct catalytic hydrogenation of 4-nitrophenol [36]. The conventional method for catalytic hydrogenation of 4-nitrophenol has been performed using iron/acid as a reducing agent with high temperature and pressure [37] and hence this technique is not a convenient one to follow, especially for large-scale production. However, other metallic reagents containing Zn, Al and Sn have led to the production of the undesirable metal oxides. In view of these backgrounds, there is a need for an alternative, effective and eco-friendly method for the reduction of 4-nitrophenol. Several homogeneous metal nanoparticles, viz. Pt, Au and AgNPs have been studied widely as a catalyst for the reduction of different organic compounds [38–40]. However, in order to reduce the expenditure of the reactions, the AgNPs have been immobilized onto the insoluble matrixes and thus derived the heterogeneous nanoparticle catalyst. This type of heterogeneous nanoparticle catalyst is generally inexpensive and also enables us to recover back easily for further use. While accepting the merits of heterogeneous nanoparticle catalyst, it is also a fact that its catalytic activity is lower than the homogeneous catalyst. Hence, effort towards the preparation of heterogeneous nanoparticle catalyst with enhanced activity is always an adoring area of current interest. Specifically, in the preparation, the polymer matrixes have received a greater attention than inorganic matrixes because of their flexibility. In view of these backgrounds, in this study, we have focused on the preparation of heterogeneous nanoparticle catalyst through immobilization of AgNPs onto the bead-shaped polymer matrixes functionalized with N-vinylimidazole and its catalytic activity was inspected with reduction of 4-nitrophenol reaction. 2 Experimental methods Monomers such as styrene (Alfa-Aaeser), N-vinyl imidazole (Alfa Aaeser) and divinyl benzene (Alfa-Aaeser) were used with prior purification. Other chemicals like gelatin (BDH), poly(vinylalcohol) (Fluka), azobisisobutyronitrile (Kochlight, USA), boric acid, sodium nitrite, sodium hydroxide and AgNO3 (BDH) were used as a metal precursor, NaBH4, 4-nitrophenol, solvents like ethanol and methanol, cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) and D.D water were used as such without any further purification. 2.1 Purification method for the monomers The monomer was purified by treating twice with NaOH (10%) to remove the 4-tert-butylcatechol (TBC) inhibitor, washing three times with distilled water and then the supernatant was transferred to column packed with dried K2CO3 over the aluminum oxide as adsorbent. Finally, the purified monomer eluted from the column was dehydrated using anhydrous sodium sulfate before use. 2.2 Characterization The surface morphology of the polymer-supported poly(N-vinylimidazole) (PS-PVIm) and PS-PVIm beads immobilized with silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) were analyzed by scanning electron microscope (SEM). The measurements were performed on HITACHI S-3000H scanning electron microscope at an acceleration voltage of 20kev with different working distance. A strip of double-sided conducting carbon tape was applied to the metal stub and the beads were deposited on the carbon tape and the sample was allowed to be scanned. UV–vis absorption spectrum was measured on TECHOMP UV–vis spectrophotometer. The background correction was made by absorption spectrum of water for catalysis studies. FT-IR analysis was carried out on BRUKER, TENSOR 27 model instrument. The crystallographic structure and size of the AgNPs immobilized onto the PS-PVIm beads were obtained by X-ray diffraction (XRD) on desktop X-ray diffractometer, using a Cu Kα-monochromotized radiation source (λ =1.54045) operating at 30kV and 15mA and scanned at the rate of 1–100 min−1 over the range of 50-700. 2.3 Preparation of cross-linked poly(styrene)-co-poly(N-vinylimidazole) bead Two types of common matrices, viz. insoluble cross-linked polymer-supported poly(N-vinylimidazole) (PS-PVIm) beads were prepared by modifying the earlier method [41] and by fixing the cross-linking monomer ratio as 2% (Type-I) and 10% (Type-II) respectively. The method involves the suspension co-polymerization of styrene (ST), N-vinylimidazole (N-VIm) (functional monomer) cross-linked with divinylbenzene (DVB). By fixing 2% cross-linking (amount of divinylbenzene (DVB)) and 25% active site (amount of N-vinylimidazole), the organic phase was maintained at 82.5g and aqueous phase at 225g. Exactly gelatin (1.35g), boric acid (2.55g) and polyvinyl alcohol (2.25g) were thoroughly dissolved in 30, 60 and 130ml of double distilled hot water (50°C). The poly(vinyl) alcohol was to maintain the viscosity of the medium. Then these solutions were mixed together at room temperature and then the pH of the mixed solution was adjusted to 10 by the addition of 25% aqueous sodium hydroxide solution and sodium nitrite (0.1g) was added to maintain the conformation of gelatin. The aqueous phase became clear only after adjusting the pH to 10. It was then transferred to 250ml three necked RB flask equipped with overhead mechanical stirrer and reflux condenser. Nitrogen was passed continuously and the temperature was maintained at 50°C. After half an hour (maintaining the above condition), the organic phase containing DVB (3.6ml), styrene (st) (64.6ml) and AIBN (0.4125g) was thoroughly mixed and added to the reaction flask. The blade level of the stirrer was adjusted so that the tips were in organic phase and most of the blade in aqueous phase. Subsequently, the thermostat temperature was increased to 70°C and the stirring speed was maintained at 400rpm using tachometer. Then after three hours, i.e. after the partial polymerization of St and DVB, functional monomer viz., N-vinylimidazole was added and the terpolymerization reaction was allowed to proceed to completion for 48h. The resulting terpolymer beads were filtered through a Buckner funnel and washed with hot water and cold methanol repeatedly until the wash solution did not turn cloudy upon the addition of water. Then it was dried at 60°C in a vacuum oven for 2 days and thus obtained 2% cross-linked Type-I beads, viz. polymer-supported poly(styrene) functionalized with poly(vinylimidazole) beads (PS-PVIm). The dried beads were sieved into different mesh sizes, and similarly, the Type-II polymer-supported poly(styrene) functionalized with poly(vinylimidazole) beads (PS-PVIm) were prepared by adopting the same experimental procedure and methodology except the variation in amount of cross-linking monomer (DVB) load, 10% of DVB (18ml), 25% of N-vinylimidazole (functional monomer) and remaining 65% of styrene were taken and prepared the PS-PVIm beads, after drying the resulting beads were sieved into different mesh sizes. The representative mesh size, viz. +100 to 120 arrived in both Type-I and Type-II beads were analyzed with FT-IR, XRD, SEM and EDAX. 2.4 Preparation of two types of heterogeneous nanoparticle catalysts through immobilization of AgNPs onto the PS-PVIm matrices (PS-PVIm-AgNPs) The immobilization of AgNPs onto the Type-I and Type-II PS-VIm matrices were performed using AgNO3 as a metal precursor (Scheme 1 ). That is, 500mg of Type-I and Type-II PS-VIm bead matrices with mesh size of ±100–120 were taken individually in a 100ml round-bottomed flask and kept for swelling in 50ml of ethanol for overnight. The respective polymer beads in the flask were purged with nitrogen for 1h and then metal precursor solution, viz. AgNO3 (5mg, 1.5×10−4 mol) was added to each container. Then the solution was stirred and refluxed in an oil bath with a magnetic stirrer at 80°C. Adequate care should be taken in such a way that the reaction mixture should not be exposed to light so as to avoid the photochemical reduction of Ag+. After ten minutes, the colorless solution was changed to light yellow and after 1h it was changed to dark yellow. The solution was stirred for at least 45min, then, 2equiv. of NaBH4 was added to the respective containers and were refluxed with stirring for 24h, and the resulting solution containing beads was dark yellow in color which in turn was filtered through Buchner funnel, washed with ethanol (3 times) and dried in oven at 60°C for 12h and thus respective AgNPs immobilized Type-I and Type-II heterogeneous nanoparticle catalyst, viz. polymer supported poly(styrene) functionalized with poly(vinylimidazole) beads immobilized with AgNPs (PS-PVIm-AgNPs) catalysts were obtained. The change of color (from light yellow to dark yellow) was the indication for reduction of Ag+ to AgNPs. The formation/immobilization of AgNPs onto the PS-PVIm matrices irrespective of the type of catalyst was confirmed from normal micrograph, UV–vis, FT-IR, XRD, EDAX and SEM analyses. 2.5 Comparative catalytic activity of Type-I and Type-II PS-PVIm-AgNPs catalysts for the reduction of 4-nitrophenol The comparative catalytic efficiency of Type-I and Type-II PS-PVIm-AgNPs catalysts was examined separately by conducting the reduction of 4-nitrophenol maintaining under identical pseudo-first order condition (Scheme 2 ). The individual kinetic experiments were performed by taking 50ml two-necked RB flask to which, 5ml of 4-NP (0.2mM), 5ml of aqueous NaBH4 (100mM) and 25mg of Type-I and Type-II catalysts were added individually. The respective reaction medium was agitated with magnetic stirrer at ambient temperature. The progress of each reaction was monitored by withdrawing the samples at regular intervals (5min) and the same analyzed through UV–vis spectrophotometer by maintaining the wavelength range from 200 to 800nm. The pseudo-first order rate constant of the reaction catalyzed by the respective catalyst was calculated by measuring the disappearance of characteristic peak, viz. NO2 group quantitatively at 400nm collected at regular intervals. The rate constant was calculated using the following formula irrespective of the reaction. k obs = ln [ ( A ∞ − A 0 ) / ( A ∞ − A t ) ] t where A 0 is the initial absorbance, A t the absorbance at time ‘t’, A ∞the absorbance at infinity time. Detailed kinetics study and recycle efficiency were also studied with Type-I catalyst. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterization of PS-PVIm beads and PS-PVIm-AgNPs catalysts Two types of heterogeneous nanoparticle catalysts, viz. polymer supported poly(styrene) functionalized with poly(vinylimidazole) beads immobilized with AgNPs (PS-PVIm-AgNPs) catalysts were prepared using PS-PVIm matrices derived from 2% (Type-I) and 10% (Type-II) load of cross-linking monomer (DVB). FT-IR spectra of the Type-I and Type-II PS-PVIm beads are shown in Fig. 1a and c respectively. Both the spectra showed the characteristic peaks including aromatic CH at 3059cm−1, aliphatic CH(str) at 2923cm−1 and vibration for CH2(bend) at 1450cm−1, and these peaks in turn evidenced the presence of CH2 backbone in the matrices. Similarly, the other three peaks at 698, 1492 and 1630cm−1 were due to CN(str), CN(str,ring) and CN(str,ring) respectively and thus confirmed the functionalization of N-vinylimidazole in the polymeric network. The immobilization of AgNPs onto the Type-I PS-PVIm and Type-II PS-PVIm matrices was also established with FT-IR through spectra shown in Fig. 1b and d respectively. Both the spectra revealed that the characteristic peak, viz. CN stretching noticed at 1630cm−1 was shifted to 1664cm−1 in Type-I and 1668cm−1 for Type-II catalysts. This shifting is normally possible if AgNPs binds with CN group and thus indicating the immobilization of AgNPs on PS-PVIm beads. Similarly, the formation of AgNPs was also confirmed from color of the beads in solution. Initially, the PS-PVIm beads (Type-I and Type-II) were existing in white color, and after the addition of AgNO3, the solution containing beads were changed from white to light/pale yellow. Then the reduction of immobilized Ag+ to Ag0 was ensured from the change of beads color from pale yellow to dark yellow and thus confirming the formation/immobilization of AgNPs onto PS-PVIm matrices and thus yielding the respective PS-PVIm-AgNPs catalyst. Additionally, the formation/immobilization of AgNPs onto the PS-PVIm matrices was again verified through UV–vis analysis. That is, the respective catalysts were treated individually with cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) solution through sonication for 45min and extraction of the immobilized AgNPs. After sonication, the color of the extracted CTAB solution was changed into dark yellow irrespective of the type of catalysts. These solutions were analyzed with UV at ambient temperature and from the obtained UV spectrum, it is clear that irrespective of the type of solution, the surface plasmon resonance peak was noticed at 422nm (Fig. 2a and b) and this observation has strongly confirmed the formation of AgNPs which are immobilized onto the respective PS-PVIm matrices. Similar types of earlier studies have also revealed that at ambient temperature the Plasmon peak was red shifted to 410–420nm as the particle size increased [42]. The surface morphology of both types of PS-PVIm beads (control) and their corresponding PS-PVIm-AgNPs catalysts were studied with SEM analysis. The images for Type-I PS-PVIm and Type-II PS-PVIm beads and their corresponding catalysts, viz. Type-I PS-PVIm-AgNPs and Type-II PS-PVIm-AgNPs were shown in Fig. 3a and b and Fig. 3c and d respectively. Fig. 3a and b shows smooth surfaces for Type-I PS-PVIm and Type-II PS-PVIm beads and also spherical surfaces without any heterogeneity. In contrast, Fig. 3c and d shows the heterogeneous surface with appearance of white patches. The conversion of homogeneous surface to heterogeneous with distributed white patches is the contribution of AgNPs immobilized onto the PS-PVIm matrices irrespective of the type of the catalyst. Gearhert et al. reported the analog results in the surface morphology studies of nanoparticles [43]. Similarly, earlier we have also reported the same observation for polymer-supported dendritic nanocatalysts immobilized with gold nanoparticles [44]. The other unique observation was, on comparing Fig. 3c and d, the surface morphology of Type-I PS-PVIm-AgNPs catalyst contains more white patches than Type-II PS-PVIm-AgNPs, in other words, it advocates the lower availability of AgNPs/imidazole nitrogen in the Type-II PS-PVIm-AgNPs. That is, despite adding equal volume of functional monomer (PVIm) in both the catalysts preparation, but in spite of that the lower availability of white patches in Type-II is noticed. This is due to addition of higher amount of cross-linking monomer (DVB) to the functional monomer, viz. poly(vinylimidazole) which in turn may attract effectively the PVIm monomer and bury more amount of PVIm inside the polymeric network as compared with the Type-I PS-PVIm-AgNPs. As a result, the availability of poly(vinylimidazole) ring onto the surface of the beads might decrease substantially in Type-II and thus reflect lowering the availability of imidazole nitrogen on the surface and hence lower binding/distribution of AgNPs. In contrast, in Type-I PS-PVIm-AgNPs, poly (vinylimidazole) moiety is available largely onto the surface because, since lower volume of (2%) of crosslinking (DVB) monomer was added in the preparation that in turn cannot bury much of the PVIm monomer inside the polymer network, as a result of which most of the PVIm was grafted onto the surface of the beads and thus facilitated the attraction/immobilization of more number of silver ions onto the surface. The immobilization of AgNPs onto the matrix was due to the strong localization of Ag+ ions by coordination with nitrogen atom present at the third position of the vinyl imidazole moiety [25] which on further reduction converted into Ag0 (AgNPs). Therefore, these observations have strongly suggested that AgNPs were effectively immobilized on Type-I than Type-II PS-PVIm matrices. Similarly, the elemental composition of Type-I and Type-II PS-PVIm beads (control) and their corresponding Type-I and Type-II PS-PVIm-AgNPs catalysts were also determined with EDS and their corresponding spectra show the percentage of C, N and Ag elements. It is understood that the Type-I PS-PVIm beads contain more amount of nitrogen (42.45%) on the surface than Type-II PS-PVIm beads surface (24.54%). Similarly, the atomic percentage of Ag available on the surface was determined as 1.14 for Type-I and 0.29 for Type-II catalyst. These results again depict the early inference, that is, at increased volume of cross-linking load in Type-II, most of the functional moieties are buried inside the matrix and hence reflected the lower availability of imidazole group onto the surface and thus resulted in the lower concentration of nitrogen and Ag on the surface than with Type-I catalyst. To determine the size of the AgNPs immobilized on the heterogeneous nanoparticle catalysts, Type-I and Type-II PS-PVIm-AgNPs catalysts and their corresponding PS-PVIm beads (control) were characterized with XRD analysis. Both Type-I and Type-II PS-PVIm beads (control) show two well-defined peaks at 2θ value of 10 and 19.5 and these two peaks correspond to the contribution of their poly(styrene) supported poly(vinylimidazole) network. After immobilization of AgNPs, the obtained catalysts, viz. Type-I PS-PVIm-AgNPs and Type-II PS-PVIm-AgNPs have shown diffraction patterns with appearance of new peaks having 2θ values at 38.1, 44.1, 64.3 and 77.1 which correspond to (111) (200) (220) and (311) planes. These planes are indexed as a face-centered-cubic structure of silver. From the XRD analysis, the size of the AgNPs immobilized onto both Type-I and Type-II PS-PVIm beads were calculated using Debye–Scherer equation and observed as 10nm and 14.6nm in diameter respectively. Further, it is also observed that, the polymer network peaks noticed at 2θ values of 10 and 19.5 are maintaining with same intensity in both the catalysts and thus indicate that the immobilization of AgNPs does not disturb/damage the basic structure of the polymeric network during the preparation of the catalyst. 3.2 Comparative catalytic activity of Type-I and Type-II PS-PVIm-AgNPs catalysts for the reduction of 4-nitrophenol The comparative catalytic activity of the Type-I and Type-II PS-PVIm-AgNPs catalysts were examined through reduction of 4-nitrophenol as a model reaction with NaBH4 under identical pseudo-first order reaction conditions using UV–vis spectrophotometer. In this experiment, the concentration of borohydride ion used as reductant, exceeded (100 times) that of 4-NP. Since the concentration of NaBH4 was very high, the reduction rates were assumed to be independent of borohydride concentration, i.e. it remained constant throughout the reaction. The observed pseudo-first order rate constant was used to evaluate the performance of the catalysts. The occurrence of reduction of 4-NP was quantitatively followed by measuring the disappearance of NO2 peak at 400nm against the time through UV irrespective of the catalysts. Control experiment (without catalyst) was also performed and it reveals that the peak due to 4-phenolate ions at 400nm remained unaltered even for two days, and this shows that the reaction is kinetically restricted even though the reaction is a thermodynamically feasible process involving standard reduction potential for 4-NP/4-AP=−0.76 and H3B03/BH− =1.33V versus NHE [45]. But in the presence of catalyst, the aqueous solution of 4-nitrophenol initially gave a maximum absorption peak at 317nm, and when a freshly prepared ice cold aqueous solution of NaBH4 was added the color of the solution changed from light yellow to dark yellow without any induction period and thus formed the 4-nitrophenolate ion which bathochromically red shifted from 317 to 400nm. However, the addition of small amount of catalyst with stirring caused gradual fading of yellow color and then the reaction mixture turned colorless. The time-dependent UV–vis spectrum (Fig. 4 ) of this catalytic reaction displayed a significant decrease in peak height at 400nm associated with the concomitant evolution of new peak at 293nm which confirmed the formation of 4-aminophenol. The pseudo-first order rate constants (k obs) at 295K were determined and the obtained values are presented in Table 1 . Although, same amount of functional monomer (N-vinylimidazole) and metal load were added for the preparation of Type-I and Type-II catalysts, yet Type-I PS-PVIm-AgNPs catalyst showed six-fold enhanced activity than Type-II PS-PVIm-AgNPs catalyst. The higher activity of Type-I was due to the increased immobilization of AgNPs onto the beads surface than with Type-II catalyst surface. Similarly, the k obs for the recovered Type-I PS-PVIm-AgNPs catalyst showed the same activity than with its first cycle activity and the observed k obs values were plotted against number of recycle time (Fig. 5 ). It is confirmed that the stability of the Type-I catalyst is sustained without any loss (or) leaching of catalytic AgNPs from PS-PVIm matrices. Hence, this superior and stable catalyst, viz. Type-I PS-PVIm-AgNPs was employed to determine the thorough kinetics of the same reduction of 4-nitrophenol by varying the experimental parameters such as [substrate], [catalyst] and [NaBH4]. 3.3 Kinetics of 4-nitrophenol using Type-I PS-PVIm-AgNPs In heterogeneous catalysis, the rate of the reaction generally increases linearly with the amount of the catalyst. With a view to examine the effect of Type-I PS-PVIm-AgNPs, the said reduction of 4-NP reaction was performed by varying the catalyst amount from 15 to 35mg keeping the other parameters constant. Yang-Chuang et al. also studied similar type of variations [46]. The plot derived from observed rate constant against the amount of catalyst is shown in Fig. 6a. From this plot, it is understand that on increasing the amount of Type-I PS-PVIm-AgNPs, the rate constant is also parallely increased. This is quite obvious that at higher load of catalyst amount, the active nanoparticle is also available largely that contributed enhanced rate constant. Jana et al. observed the same trend of results for the kinetic study of reduction of 4-NP using resin-bound Ag nanocomposites [47]. The effect of [NaBH4] was also studied by fixing the concentration range from 80 to 120mM keeping other parameters as constant. The pseudo-first order rate constants were evaluated and plotted against the NaBH4 concentration (Fig. 6b). The observed rate constants increased with the increase in the concentration of NaBH4. Analog trend in the rate constant with increasing [NaBH4] was already reported by Henglein et al. [48]. On increasing the [NaBH4], the adsorption of NaBH4 onto the nanoparticle surfaces also parallely increases, as a result, the release of electrons from BH4 − (donor) to the 4-NP (receptor) increases [49]. Further, it is worth to state that under the fixed concentration of NaBH4 the reduced product viz., 4-AP is not oxidized further because, the liberated hydrogen from borohydride purged out the air and has prevented the oxidation. In addition, evolution of small bubbles of hydrogen on the catalyst surface helped in mixing of the solution and thus offering the favorable conditions to increase the reaction rates. In order to study the influence of [substrate] on the rate of reduction of 4-NP in the presence of Type-I PS-PVIm-AgNPs catalyst and NaBH4, the concentration of 4-NP was varied from 0.08 to 0.14mM. The pseudo-first order rate constants were calculated and plotted against the [substrate]. From the plot (Fig. 6c), it is implied that the rate constant increased with the increase in the [substrate]. Normally, the metallic nanoparticles strongly catalyze the reduction reactions by transferring electrons from BH4 − ions [50] to the substrate after the adsorption of both substrate and NaBH4 ions onto the catalyst surface. In the same line of observation, in this study also, when the [substrate] was increased, the probability of adsorption of more number of 4-nitrophenolate ions onto the catalyst surface was also parallely increased and thus enhanced the rate constants. Added to this fact, NaBH4 present in aqueous medium is a strong nucleophile, because of its diffusive nature and high electron injection capability, transfers electron to the substrate via metal particles which in turn helps to overcome the kinetic barrier of the reduction reaction to form 4-aminophenol. Similar type of results on the rate of 4-NP reduction with addition of substrate was reported by Pal et al. [51]. 4 Conclusions Two types of new bead-shaped heterogeneous nanoparticle catalysts, viz. polymer-supported polymer(styrene) matrices immobilized silver nanoparticle catalysts, viz. Type-I PS-PVIm-AgNPs and Type-II PS-PVIm-AgNPs were prepared by fixing the cross-linking load as 2% and 10% respectively and the load of functional monomer, i.e. N-vinylimidazole as a constant (25%). The resulting two types of polymer-immobilized silver nanoparticles catalysts were characterized with FT-IR, UV–vis, SEM and EDS analyses. The appearance of CN(str,ring) at 1630cm−1 and AgN(str,ring) at 1664cm−1 for Type-I and 1668cm−1 for Type-II catalyst in the FT-IR spectra, change of color of the beads from colorless to dark yellow and appearance of surface plasmon resonance peak at 422nm in UV, the change of smooth surface (control) to heterogeneous surface (catalyst) noticed in SEM, enhancement of amount of surface nitrogen and AgNPs load determined in EDS for Type-I catalysts have strongly confirmed the more grafting of poly(vinylimidazole) moiety as well as more load of AgNPs immobilization onto the surface of PS-PVIm matrices than with Type-II catalyst. The XRD pattern reveals that the size of the AgNPs immobilized onto both Type-I and Type-II catalysts were determined as 10nm and 14.6nm respectively. The activity of the catalysts was assessed based on the pseudo-first order rate constants of the reduction of 4-nitrophenol. The 6 fold enhancement of k obs noticed in Type-I catalyst has strongly confirmed the superiority of the catalyst than Type-II. Further, thorough kinetic studies showed that the rate constant increased linearly with the [substrate], [catalyst] and [NaBH4]. This is specifically attributed to the more quantum of effective substrate interaction with catalyst (AgNPs) especially at higher load of substrate, catalyst, and NaBH4. Particularly, increased concentration of NaBH4 has led to supply more quanta of electrons that directly contributed to the increased k obs. The newly prepared catalysts are stable, efficient, eco-friendly, easy to prepare and easily recyclable by simple filtration. Moreover, since the catalysts are in spherical form (beads) they can be conveniently packed into column/flow reactors and thus enable us to conduct the reactions in continuous mode and hence it may attract potential industrial applications in future. coredata.dc:description: Two types of bead-shaped stable heterogeneous nanoparticle catalysts, viz. polymer-supported poly(styrene) functionalized with poly(vinylimidazole) immobilized silver nanoparticles (PS-PVIm-AgNPs) were prepared from poly(styrene)-co-poly(N-vinylimidazole) polymer matrices derived from 2% (Type-I) and 10% (Type-II) cross-linking monomer divinylbenzene and AgNO3 as a metal precursor. The appearance of surface plasmon resonance peak at 422nm in UV and AgN(str,ring) peaks noticed at 1664cm−1 for Type-I and 1668cm−1 for Type-II catalysts in FT-IR confirms the immobilization of AgNPs onto PS-PVIm. The SEM and EDAX results prove that the Type-I catalyst has heterogeneous morphology with more white patches and enhanced amount of surface nitrogen and AgNPs than Type-II. The size of the AgNPs on Type-I and Type-II catalysts was measured as 10nm and 14.6nm from XRD, respectively. The comparative catalytic study for the reduction of 4-nitrophenol reveals that the pseudo-first order rate constant (k obs) for Type-I catalyst was relatively superior (k obs =5.12×10−4) than Type-II (k obs =1.20×10−4) due to the addition of high cross-linking load in Type-II. For the same reaction with Type-I catalyst, the variation of [substrate], [catalyst] and [NaBH4] was directly proportional to k obs. The stability and reusability of the catalyst were observed good and sustained even at six cycles.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis and characterization of silver nanoparticles supported on surface-modified poly(N-vinylimidazale) as catalysts for the reduction of 4-nitrophenol
